description:
Shuu's entire world was shattered after a meteorite crashed into Japan, unleashing the lethal Apocalypse Virus. The chaos and anarchy born of the outbreak cost Shuu his family and reduced him to a timid, fearful shell of the boy he'd once been. His life took another unexpected turn after a chance encounter with the stunning pop star, Inori. This mysterious beauty introduced Shuu to the King's Right Hand: a genetic mutation that allows him to reach into hearts of mortals and turn them into weapons.

Shuu finds himself caught in the crossfire between those who desperately seek his newfound strength. On one side lurks a clandestine government agency, and on the other, Inori and the spirited band of rebels known as Funeral Parlor. The choice is Shuu's to make - and the world is his to change.

(Source: Funimation)

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Terrorism
tags.description: Centers around the activities of a terrorist or terrorist organization.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Pandemic
tags.description: Prominently features a disease prevalent over a whole country or the world.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Incest
tags.description: Features sexual or romantic relations between characters who are related by blood.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Yandere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is obsessively in love with another, to the point of acting deranged or violent.

tags.name: Nekomimi
tags.description: Humanoid characters with cat-like features such as cat ears and a tail.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Disability
tags.description: A work that features one or more characters with a physical, mental, cognitive, or developmental condition that impairs, interferes with, or limits the person's ability to engage in certain tasks or actions.

tags.name: Female Harem
tags.description: Main cast features the protagonist plus several female characters who are romantically interested in them.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ccarrollbeard) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/colleen.clinkenbeardvoiceactress)

An American voice actress and theatre actress, working mainly in the commercial and dubbing industries. She has also served as ADR director, line producer, and script writer for several anime titles for Funimation.

She gave birth to her first son, Rhodes Vandelo Carroll, on September 4, 2014.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ichirou_o)

Waseda University graduate. Best known as the co-creator of [Code Geass](https://anilist.co/anime/1575/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/265406784) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/tetsuro.araki.75)

Joined [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) in 1999 as a production manager, making his storyboard and episode director debut with [Galaxy Angel](https://anilist.co/anime/383/) just two years later. In 2005, he made his proper directorial debut with [Otogi-juushi Akazukin](https://anilist.co/anime/402/), a single-episode OVA which was aimed more at figure collectors than at anime fans. Its popularity birthed the full-length series and manga which both came out afterwards.

In 2006, Araki helmed his first big project with [Death Note](https://anilist.co/anime/1535/), which gained him international praise. He has since gone on to direct numerous series from originals such as [Guilty Crown](https://anilist.co/anime/10793/) and [Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress](https://anilist.co/anime/21196/), to the massively successful adaptation of [Attack on Titan](https://anilist.co/anime/16498/), whose production Araki left with the studio change.

He's been close friends with [Takayuki Hirao](https://anilist.co/staff/102247/) since their days at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). The two have frequently collaborated on numerous projects.

Married to [Aya Hida](https://anilist.co/staff/144626/).

Freelance, however primarily works at [WIT Studio](https://anilist.co/studio/858/) with Animation Producer [Kazuki Yamanaka](https://anilist.co/staff/196459/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/265406784) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/tetsuro.araki.75)

The founder and former representative director of [Funimation](https://anilist.co/studio/102/).

**Non-anime roles:**
- Policeman in "Chuck E. Cheese in the Galaxy 5000"

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1519543115367206913)

Originating from [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/). Currently affiliated with [Wit Studio](https://anilist.co/studio/858/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鏑木ひろ)

Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/).

[Website](http://www.sawanohiroyuki.com/) | [Website (nZk)](http://www.sh-nzk.net) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/sawano_nZk) | [Instagram (Official)](https://www.instagram.com/hiroyukisawano.official/) | [Instagram (Personal)](https://www.instagram.com/sawano__hiroyuki/) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/user/SawanoHiroyukiSMEJ) | [Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/0Riv2KnFcLZA3JSVryRg4y?si=KaE_XDXqSRewfXXsxBNzoA) | [Apple Music](https://music.apple.com/artist/hiroyuki-sawano/156620523) | [Deezer](https://www.deezer.com/artist/1315147) 

Composer and musician represented by VV-ALKLINE since 2017. He was previously with Legendoor from 2006 to 2017. 
Sawano began practicing the piano at an early age, and studied composition, arrangement, orchestration, and piano under Nobuchika Tsuboi from the age of 17.

Active as a composer since 2004, he first gained recognition for his work on the Team Medical Dragon TV drama in 2006. He made his debut as an anime composer in 2006 on [Soul Link](https://anilist.co/anime/854/). In 2009, he released his first solo album *musica*, which included some of his more popular songs done for TV shows. In 2014, he launched a new vocal song project under the name "SawanoHiroyuki[nZk]", producing the first album *UnChild* with [Aimer](https://anilist.co/staff/107859/) as the vocalist under the name SawanoHiroyuki[nZk]:Aimer. Since then his songs under this vocal song project have also been used as the opening and ending themes for various anime.

He has cited [Joe Hisaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/100738/), [Youko Kanno](https://anilist.co/staff/95508/), [Hans Zimmer](https://anilist.co/staff/104669/) and Danny Elfman as major inspirations.

Non-anime role:

• **Xenoblade Chronicles X (music)** 
• **Xenoblade Chronicles X Definitive Edition (music)**

__[Twitter](https://twitter.com/dajinman)__ | __[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/tomoyuki.kurokawa.7)__

__Tomoyuki Kurokawa__ is a Japanese director, episode director and storyboard artist. He was affiliated with studio Bee Train.

He made his lead directorial debut with the OVA _[Murder Princess](https://anilist.co/anime/1696/Murder-Princess/)_, and had his first lead director role with the release of _[Psychic Detective Yakumo](https://anilist.co/anime/7662/Shinrei-Tantei-Yakumo/)_.
Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/).
Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/).
Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/).
Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/).
Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tomohikoito0218)

Originating from [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/).

__Hiroyuki Yoshino__ is a Japanese script/screenwriter and series composer.

Since the beginning of his career he has been working with Studio Sunrise, he has scripted various of its anime including [Mai-HIME](https://anilist.co/anime/98/MaiHiME/), [Code Geass: Lelouch of the Rebellion](https://anilist.co/anime/1575/Code-Geass-Hangyaku-no-Lelouch) and [Mai-Otome](https://anilist.co/anime/99/MaiOtome/).

Upon graduating from the Waseda University's School of Literature, he went on to become a teacher of world history at a high school. After this, Hiroyuki joined the staff of Tokuma Shoten's Animage magazine as a writer. It was in this magazine that the Sunrise producer Furusato Naotake offered him a position in the studio as a screenwriter.

Since joining Studio Sunrise, the first series in which he was the head-writer, as well as the series composer, was the series Mai-HIME, followed-up by [Mai-Otome](https://anilist.co/anime/98/MaiHiME/) and [Mai-Otome Zwei](https://anilist.co/anime/1609/MaiOtome-Zwei/). He also went on to supervise, as an extension to this work. Hiroyuki has also authored the manga adaption of [Mai-Otome](https://anilist.co/manga/31069/MaiOtome/) (alongside Tatsuhito Higuchi), and went on to write numerous other manga series.

__Hiroyuki Yoshino__ is a Japanese script/screenwriter and series composer.

Since the beginning of his career he has been working with Studio Sunrise, he has scripted various of its anime including [Mai-HIME](https://anilist.co/anime/98/MaiHiME/), [Code Geass: Lelouch of the Rebellion](https://anilist.co/anime/1575/Code-Geass-Hangyaku-no-Lelouch) and [Mai-Otome](https://anilist.co/anime/99/MaiOtome/).

Upon graduating from the Waseda University's School of Literature, he went on to become a teacher of world history at a high school. After this, Hiroyuki joined the staff of Tokuma Shoten's Animage magazine as a writer. It was in this magazine that the Sunrise producer Furusato Naotake offered him a position in the studio as a screenwriter.

Since joining Studio Sunrise, the first series in which he was the head-writer, as well as the series composer, was the series Mai-HIME, followed-up by [Mai-Otome](https://anilist.co/anime/98/MaiHiME/) and [Mai-Otome Zwei](https://anilist.co/anime/1609/MaiOtome-Zwei/). He also went on to supervise, as an extension to this work. Hiroyuki has also authored the manga adaption of [Mai-Otome](https://anilist.co/manga/31069/MaiOtome/) (alongside Tatsuhito Higuchi), and went on to write numerous other manga series.

[Twitter 1](https://twitter.com/i/user/1030757741193646080) | [Twitter 2](https://twitter.com/i/user/1467985113997021188) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCtOegRvxx7rZNiIsMyEPIfA) | [Website](https://www.hidetoshiohmori19591105.com/)

After graduation, Oomori moved to Tokyo and began his career at Studio Annapuru in 1981, a small sub-contracting studio founded by [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/). Soon after he left the studio and joined Bebow, a studio ran by [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/). There he mainly worked on mecha shows produced by [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/). He also showed up as an animation director on [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/).

Oomori left Bebow in 1986, and participated in the establishment of Atelier Giga. Around this time he also served as an animation director on [Mobile Suit Gundam: Char's Counterattack](https://anilist.co/anime/87/), one of his best-known works.

In the '90s he was also active in the video game industry. Notably as an animation director on Final Fantasy VII.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/y_kaele)

After graduating from Yoyogi Animation Gakuin, he joined an adult game brand (スタジオルクス) which he soon left. He entered [Studio Pastoral](https://anilist.co/studio/299/Studio-Pastoral) after which he started working on [Shaft](https://anilist.co/studio/44/Shaft) shows and became part of the main staff for most of their works.

[DeviantART](http://redjuice999.deviantart.com/) | [Twitter](http://twitter.com/shiru) | [Pixiv](http://www.pixiv.net/member.php?id=3446) | [Vimeo](https://vimeo.com/user502976)

Designer of hololiveEN VSinger [IRyS](https://anilist.co/staff/237459/IRyS).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Sasakino00) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐々木啓悟F)

Originating from [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/). 
Previously affiliated with [A-1 Pictures](https://anilist.co/studio/561/A1-Pictures). 
Currently affiliated with [CygamesPicture](https://anilist.co/studio/6182/CygamesPictures).
